captions.text: It's really nothing...
No other feeling like riding.
Those moments when you're floating, time feels as though it stopped...
Everything else just washing away.
There's no noise, no traffic.
It's perfect.
Riding around in Austin is definitely where I'm in my element.
The city is so unique and diverse.
You have the trails, house park, literally hundreds of other places.
I, for the most part have been pedaling everywhere my entire life.
I'm one of the few BMX riders that was born and raised here in Austin.
I started riding at 7 years old.
and by 13/14 years old I remember watching legends like Joe, and Taj,
and Ruben by 9th street.
I obviously looked up to the way they rode,
but never imagined people would look up to me one day
I still feel like that kid on that bike...
It's been quite the journey, and it seems crazy that this bike has taken me all over the world.
But to come back have this your home is just...
Well, I consider myself one of the lucky ones.

comments.text:
This entire thing is spectacularly inspiring. I used to ride BMX in 1983 
when I was a kid. I never imagined anything like this back then. BMX kept 
me alive back then. It was the one thing I loved. Back then it was not a 
"thing" like it is now. Decades later as a scientist, I now find great 
inspiration from these kids doing what I truly consider Art. Thank you. ﻿

comments.text:
LMFAO cheers mate. You nailed it on the head right there brah. I'm mostly 
jus' trollin', but some parts of that country are potentially dangerous if 
you don't tread lightly. :) With every passing generation a little bit more 
fundamentalist religious stupidity is bred out of the human condition & 
it's exactly that diversity you mentioned that helps to make that happen. 
It just takes time. Science goes an awful long way too. ;) Say "NO" to 
church, "YES" to bikes. Poice.
comments.author: MrFreerideForever

comments.text:
+MrFreerideForever According to the term Bible Belt, Austin is a part of 
it. The part of Texas that I'm from is not...so maybe that's why I didn't 
know that Austin was, I've lived there for 4 years now. I can tell you 
however that Austin is a big city with people all over the world living 
there, so the diversity I suppose masks the Bible Beltness. I'm not 
ignorant, you're not ignorant...the education system sucks in all of 
America, not just Texas. :)
comments.author: Craig Jackson

comments.text:

location that has internets access. I'm not surprised that you're from 
Texas, because you appear to be about as informed & educated as someone 
from Texas. No doubt an unfortunate result of the adversely negative 
effects of the Bible Belt on your Americunt education system. A question 
that might be worth asking yourself might be "why the fuck would someone 
lucky enough to not live anywhere near a fundamentalist religious shithole 
like Texas ever wanna go anywhere near there?" There's a lot more to that 
state than a few large urban centers that would arguably be the least 
religious areas of the state. I'm fortunate enough not to live in your 
shitty religious cuntry, however I completely understand your anger, 
friend. "God bless you". :)
